{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3550860,"name":"Rishi Desai","username":"rdesai14","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/3ab097/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T01:07:00.619Z","cooked":"

Hey we’re trying to hold the algae in our intake but we can only when the motor is spinning. Dyk if we can do it off the current jumps in the motor so that when the current spikes it continuously runs the motor. We’ve been trying but for some reason it just never works properly. Was wondering if anyone else has done this before and had better ideas

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-08T01:07:00.619Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":75.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":494689,"topic_slug":"holding-motor-power","display_username":"Rishi Desai","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57090,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Head Programming for 7451"},"post_url":"/t/holding-motor-power/494689/1","custom_user_title":"Head Programming for 7451","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3550959,"name":"Pedro Braga","username":"predobrega","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T03:39:13.167Z","cooked":"

From what I understand about your problem, it seems like enabling brake mode on the motor controller would be a good start. It gives the motor a lot more resistance when unpowered. Have you done that?

If that doesn’t work, I suppose a quick hack could be to run the motor continuously at super low duty cycle, with a really low max current so it doesn’t fry itself when stalling. To be clear, I really don’t recommend this. It’s not healthy for your motor, especially if it’s one of the small ones. If just enabling brake mode isn’t enough, you should probably look into revising the mechanics of the design.

Yea we already have it on break.

Then I suppose the next thing to do is check how much you can do on the mechanical side of things. Do you think it’s possible to add more reduction?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-08T03:57:00.694Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":27.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":494689,"topic_slug":"holding-motor-power","display_username":"Pedro Braga","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":57090,"username":"rdesai14","name":"Rishi Desai","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/3ab097/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/holding-motor-power/494689/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3551148,"name":"Rahul Yarlagadda","username":"Knufire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knufire/{size}/67820_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T12:37:31.666Z","cooked":"
predobrega:

run the motor continuously at super low duty cycle, with a really low max current so it doesn’t fry itself when stalling.

This is a totally fine thing to do, you just have to plan accordingly. Most of the vendors have published locked-rotor testing data that shows you exactly how long you can stall a motor at various currents before they fail. As long as you’re at a current that the motor can handle indefinitely, you should be fine. We do this to keep the algae in our robot.

If you’re trying to detect when you have a ball via motor current, the easiest way to debug is to log your motor current out to SmartDashboard and use a tool like Glass or AdvantageScope to plot out the current. You can then apply some filters and figure out a threshold to switch from “intaking” to “holding”.

We set our Algae Manipulator motor stator current limit to 10A. That is sufficient to grab the Algae, but not too high to cause damage to the Neo 550. https://youtube.com/shorts/5IWHYwWpIvc?si=DmgqYfKN0R0Juzg9

So when u do this? Do you just let that command run or do you have it on a default command to let it hold the algae while you execute other maneuvers

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-08T16:15:46.067Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":51,"readers_count":50,"score":15.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":494689,"topic_slug":"holding-motor-power","display_username":"Rishi Desai","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4760,"username":"billbo911","name":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57090,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Head Programming for 7451"},"post_url":"/t/holding-motor-power/494689/7","custom_user_title":"Head Programming for 7451","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3551227,"name":"seg9585","username":"seg9585","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seg9585/{size}/1974_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T16:26:37.072Z","cooked":"

Something we do for this is enable position control on the motor. For an intake, when running inwards use a standard set power command, and when the intake button is released, grab the current encoder position and PID control to that position.

What would happen if I just had the claw on a default at 10 percent power?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-08T16:42:51.995Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":43,"readers_count":42,"score":13.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494689,"topic_slug":"holding-motor-power","display_username":"Rishi Desai","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":6078,"username":"seg9585","name":"seg9585","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seg9585/{size}/1974_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57090,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Head Programming for 7451"},"post_url":"/t/holding-motor-power/494689/9","custom_user_title":"Head Programming for 7451","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3551238,"name":"seg9585","username":"seg9585","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seg9585/{size}/1974_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T16:50:33.521Z","cooked":"

Probably fine for most motors. They will generate heat but not enough to damage the motor for the seconds of time you’re holding a game piece. I wouldn’t leave it stalled indefinitely.
NEOs, Falcons, and Krakens are more tolerant of this. NEO 550 less so. I wouldn’t try this with a 775Pro as those things will burn out if you just look at them the wrong way.

The position control method I mentioned will generate a constant stall power as well technically, but only as much force as needed (in other words, probably less than 10%)

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-03-08T16:50:33.521Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":41,"readers_count":40,"score":13.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":494689,"topic_slug":"holding-motor-power","display_username":"seg9585","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57090,"username":"rdesai14","name":"Rishi Desai","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/3ab097/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6078,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/holding-motor-power/494689/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3551248,"name":"Rishi Desai","username":"rdesai14","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/3ab097/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T17:21:58.759Z","cooked":"

Okay. Thanks! Have you ever tried this with w Neo Vortex?

I was afraid of encouraging this without checking the data first, but it seems alright.
Here’s some charts from vex:


The redline chart doesn’t directly show current, but from the other charts in their page, the stall current at 4V is 48A, which seems quite high considering it ran for 300 seconds.

They don’t have the newer motors, such as the Kraken and Vortex in their page, but if even the 550 and the 775 can last this long, I’m sure the bigger motors can handle it, as long as your current is properly limited.

We just maintain the “intake” direction as we move to score. Then we chnge to “eject” for a couple seconds.
